Award.AwardTitle: Engineered Consortia for Effective Utilization of a Cyanobacterial Carbohydrate Feedstock

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Principal Investigator: Daniel Ducat
Number: 1437657

Currently, the production of biofuels relies on carbohydrate feedstocks sourced from plant-based crop species that compete with edible crop species for arable landmass and potable water. Alternative, photosynthetically derived feedstock sources of carbohydrates can uncouple biofuel production from traditional agriculture and potentially decrease the land footprint required. This project will make use of a genetically engineered strain of a photosynthetic bacterium (cyanobacterium) that will use carbon dioxide in the atmosphere and light to make sucrose (table sugar), which can be fermented to biofuels and bio-products. This microorganism is uniquely capable of rerouting the majority of its photosynthetically fixed carbon towards the production and excretion of sucrose. This engineered cyanobacterium has carbohydrate productivity potential that exceeds that of traditional plant species, and could be used for an alternative carbohydrate feedstock if effective approaches can be designed to scale culture growth and minimize the cost of feedstock recovery. The project will focus on the development of microbial consortia as one means to capitalize upon the productive capacity of these sucrose-secreting cyanobacteria. In this approach, the sugar-secreting cyanobacterium with will be co-cultured with yeast strains that efficiently utilize the carbohydrates and biologically convert them into commodity products without the requirement of sucrose purification or processing. Improvements in the capacity for the yeast stain to robustly grow and utilize cyanobacterial sugars will also ultimately improve the conversion of sucrose into biofuels and bioproducts. Towards this end, a model microbial consortium will be developed whereby engineered yeast will utilize photosynthetically produced sucrose for the production of fatty alcohols, a useful surfactant and potential biofuel additive. This project includes research and educational experiences for a graduate student, as well as undergraduate students through the Plant Genomics Program and Khorana Scholars Program at Michigan State University. In addition, this project involves engagement with an undergraduate research program at Schoolcraft College, and science policy discussions on the use of synthetic biology for biotechnology applications through a Sloan Institute sponsored Delphi policy study.

Technical Description

The overall goal of this project is to develop a co-culture system for the overproduction of sucrose from carbon dioxide and light using engineered strains of cyanobacteria and yeast. The approach relies on a two-step photobiological production of sucrose through co-culture, and will provide fundamental understanding on how engineer of inter-species interactions for this purpose. This project will make use of an engineered cyanobacterial strain, Synechococcus elongatus PCC 7942 (S. elongatus) recently developed in the PI?s laboratory that is genetically stable and capable of rerouting up to 85% of its fixed carbon towards excreted sucrose. This strain possesses a high specific activity for photosynthetic production and therefore has considerable potential as an alternative carbohydrate feedstock source if scaled culturing can mitigate three challenges, which will be addressed by the proposed research. These challenges are to 1) minimize reactor complexity and cost to a degree consistent with the commodity product value, 2) reduce the costs of purifying, processing, and delivering cyanobacterial carbohydrates to downstream applications, and 3) to reduce the risk of photobioreactor contamination. Towards this end, the project will focus on the development of a direct co-culture of S. elongates with Saccharomyces cerevisiae (yeast) that will flexibly convert the sucrose into added-value compounds. The project will explore specific strategies to improve yeast growth in co-culture, including, improvement of yeast carbon uptake, increased yeast tolerance of cyanobacterial secondary products of photosynthetic metabolism, and enhancement of the flux and specificity of carbon from cyanobacteria to yeast through engineered physical association. These strategies will be evaluated to improve yeast robustness and efficiency of conversion of carbohydrates derived from S. elongatus when grown in co-culture, and a final proof-of-principle production of cetyl alcohol is proposed through the use of an established fatty-alcohol producing yeast strain. Overall, the project has potential to impact the field of algal biofuels by providing an alternative approach for metabolic pathway engineering or by improving upon an attractive algae-derived feedstock. This project includes research and educational experiences for a graduate student, as well as undergraduates through the Plant Genomics Program and Khorana Scholars Program at Michigan State University. In addition, this project involves engagement with an undergraduate research program at Schoolcraft College, and science policy discussions on the use of synthetic biology for biotechnology applications through a Sloan Institute sponsored Delphi policy study.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview:

Broadly, the work supported by this grant has contributed to the development of a novel method for producing valuable biological compounds from sunlight and carbon dioxide through the use of microbial communities. The Award supported research on a cyanobacterium (a photosynthetic bacteria) that the group has previously engineered to produce and secrete sucrose. Such sugar-producing cyanobacteria and algae are under active investigation as possible alternative carbohydrate feedstocks that can generate the sugars for biotechnological purposes, but be more effective than traditional feedstocks (e.g., corn). In this study, the research team explored strategies to use the sugar-secreting cyanobacterium as the basis for building light-driven bacterial communities: the cyanobacterium produces and secretes sugar from light and CO2, while other heterotrophic microbes metabolize those sugars for growth and production of useful compounds (e.g. biodegradable plastics). This approach displays promise as a one-pot, flexible photoproduction system for a number of useful microbial products.

Intellectual Merit:

The funded research was designed to develop the molecular tools available for cyanobacteria generally, as well as to specifically examine strategies to increase the efficiency of the engineered cyanobacteria/heterotroph consortia. During the course of this investigation, 3 research articles and 2 review articles were published that detail the progress of the research and the state of this technology as it pertains to other bioproduction approaches. At least one additional publication will likely be published after the end of the funding period. A few highlights from this research that are representative of the progress supported by this Award are listed below.

Bioengineering of microbial consortia is an emerging field in microbiology, metabolic engineering, and synthetic biology. The more standard bioengineering approach utilizes a single species of interest (i.e., a "monoculture"). During the course of the supported research, multiple insights were gained about the nature of programmed and emergent interactions between the cyanobacteria and other heterotrophic microbes that were useful for improving the performance of the co-culture platform, but which may have some implications for construction of other microbial communities. For example, the team was able to substantially enhance the stability of the cyanobacteria/heterotroph communities over time, in the face of environmental fluctuations, and contaminating species. This allowed them to create stable consortia that lasted for the full length of the experimental observation periods (months up to a year). Similar stabilities were obtained in a specific engineered consortium that contained sucrose-secreting cyanobacteria and a bioplastic-producing (polyhydroxybutyrate: PHB) microbe, Halomonas boliviensis. The production of PHB from these communities could be improved to rival or surpass the levels produced from more established methods of engineering a single cyanobacterial species. Some of this was also disseminated through media outlets that target a much broader scientific and non-scientist audience, including Newsweek. These results help to highlight the potential for engineered, mutli-species consortia in biotechnology. 

The research also made progress on developing a new molecular tool for use in cyanobacteria: surface display. This allows protein sequences encoded within the cyanobacterial genome to be directed to the outer surface of the bacterial cell (attached to an outer membrane porin), where they can interact with the surrounding environment. The research team used this system to demonstrate proof-of-principle experiments whereby proteins displayed on the surface could attach the cyanobacterial cell to other target surfaces, including abiotic materials and other complimentary microbes. While surface display has been developed for a few other model organisms and has been used in a wide variety of biotechnology applications, no surface display system has been optimized for cyanobacteria. Further development of this tool could be of use for scaled cultivation of cyanobacteria, especially in facilitating the recovery of cell biomass, which currently is a large operating expense. 

Broader Impacts:

The funds directly supported the professional training for 2 graduate students and 1 postdoctoral candidate - at the time of this writing, one of the students had been awarded a doctorate, while the other's is pending and the postdoctoral fellow has launched a new research lab in a tenure-track position at Arizona State University. Furthermore, direct funds obtained through this award were used fo establish a collaborative effort between Schoolcraft College and Michigan State University that provided research opportunities for 4 undergraduates. Indirectly, this award has helped to support early-career scientific training for 5 undergraduate students, and has been integral to the development of additional. 

As outlined above, the research supported also has implications for the future development of applied, light-driven microbial consortia for sustainable production of commodity goods (e.g., biofuels) from renewable resources.
